issues.title: Add colorblind-friendly mode
issues.body:
## Problem

The game uses color to convey information (red for danger, green for safety) which may be difficult for colorblind players. A colorblind mode is mentioned in `godot/UI_MIGRATION_SUMMARY.md` as planned but not yet implemented.

## Solution

1. Add a "Colorblind Mode" toggle to settings
2. When enabled, add patterns/symbols to color-coded elements:
   - Doom meter: Add warning icons at thresholds
   - Resource bars: Add distinct patterns or labels
3. Store setting in GameConfig

## Files to modify

- `godot/autoload/game_config.gd` - Add setting
- `godot/scripts/ui/` - Update relevant UI components
- Settings scene

## Reference

- `godot/UI_STYLE_GUIDE.md` - Color definitions
- `godot/VISUAL_DOOM_METER.md` - Doom meter design

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Toggle exists in settings
- [ ] Visual distinction without relying solely on color (icons, patterns, or labels)
- [ ] Setting persists between sessions

---

**Good first issue** - Accessibility improvement with clear scope. See [CONTRIBUTING.md](docs/developer/CONTRIBUTING.md) to get started.

issues.title: Centralize game version constant
issues.body:
## Problem

The game version is hardcoded as a string literal in `godot/scripts/game_manager.gd:40`:

```gdscript
var game_version = "0.11.0"  # TODO: Get from GameConfig or version constant
```

This makes version bumps error-prone and inconsistent.

## Solution

1. Add a `VERSION` constant to `godot/autoload/game_config.gd`
2. Update `game_manager.gd` to use `GameConfig.VERSION`
3. Search for any other hardcoded version strings and update them

## Files to modify

- `godot/autoload/game_config.gd`
- `godot/scripts/game_manager.gd`

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Version is defined in one place
- [ ] Game runs without errors
- [ ] Version displays correctly in-game

---

**Good first issue** - Small, well-scoped refactor. See [CONTRIBUTING.md](docs/developer/CONTRIBUTING.md) to get started.

issues.title: Add keyboard shortcut documentation to in-game help
issues.body:
## Problem

The game has keyboard shortcuts (documented in `godot/KEYBOARD_SHORTCUTS_TESTING.md`) but they're not easily discoverable in-game. New players don't know about useful shortcuts.

## Solution

Add a "Keyboard Shortcuts" section to the settings or help screen displaying the most common shortcuts:

- `F5` - Quick save
- `F8` - Bug report
- `F9` - Quick load
- `Escape` - Menu
- Number keys (1-9) - Action selection

## Files to modify

- UI scene for settings/help (check `godot/scenes/`)
- Potentially `godot/scripts/ui/main_ui.gd`

## Reference

- `godot/KEYBOARD_SHORTCUTS_TESTING.md` - Full shortcut list

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Keyboard shortcuts visible somewhere in-game (settings, help, or tooltip)
- [ ] Information matches actual implemented shortcuts
- [ ] Easy to find for new players

---

**Good first issue** - Documentation + UI improvement. See [CONTRIBUTING.md](docs/developer/CONTRIBUTING.md) to get started.

issues.title: Implement save file path retrieval in bug report panel
issues.body:
## Problem

The bug report panel has a TODO for retrieving the save file path. Currently it's a stub:

```gdscript
# godot/scripts/ui/bug_report_panel.gd:130
# TODO: Implement actual save file path retrieval
pass
```

When users file bug reports, knowing the save file location helps with debugging.

## Solution

1. Implement the save file path retrieval
2. Use Godot's `user://` path to find save files
3. Display the path or "No save found" in the bug report

## Files to modify

- `godot/scripts/ui/bug_report_panel.gd`

## Helpful resources

- [Godot File Paths Documentation](https://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/tutorials/io/data_paths.html)
- `user://` resolves to the user data directory

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Bug report shows actual save file path when available
- [ ] Shows "No save file" when none exists
- [ ] No errors when opening bug report panel (F8)

---

**Good first issue** - Small, focused enhancement. See [CONTRIBUTING.md](docs/developer/CONTRIBUTING.md) to get started.

issues.title: Add unit tests for DoomSystem

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues related to test suite and testing infrastructure

issues.body:
## Problem

The `doom_system.gd` is a core game system but lacks dedicated unit tests. Other core systems like `game_state.gd` and `turn_manager.gd` have tests in `godot/tests/unit/`.

## Solution

1. Create `godot/tests/unit/test_doom_system.gd`
2. Follow the pattern from existing test files (e.g., `test_game_state.gd`)
3. Test key functions:
   - `calculate_doom_change()`
   - `apply_doom_modifier()`
   - Doom clamping (0-100 range)

## Files to create

- `godot/tests/unit/test_doom_system.gd`

## Reference files

- `godot/scripts/core/doom_system.gd` (the system to test)
- `godot/tests/unit/test_game_state.gd` (test pattern example)

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] At least 5 test cases covering core doom functionality
- [ ] Tests pass when run with GUT framework
- [ ] Tests follow existing naming conventions

---

**Good first issue** - Great way to learn the codebase through testing. See [CONTRIBUTING.md](docs/developer/CONTRIBUTING.md) to get started.

issues.title: Epic: Grant Readiness Sprint (vNext)
issues.body:
## Goal
Ship a "grant readiness" patch release that increases donor confidence: coherent versioning, improved onboarding, visible architecture promise, and at least one data-driven content win.

## Scope (child issues)
_Will be linked as issues are created_

### Core Game (this repo)
- [ ] Fix version coherence across GitHub Releases, README, and pdoom1.com
- [ ] Add in-game "What's New" / Patch Notes modal
- [ ] First 10 minutes polish pass (onboarding, clarity, friction)
- [ ] Minimal scenario/mod hook (stub ok, but real)
- [ ] Architecture & expansion promise doc (2–4 pages)
- [ ] Contributing quickstart + "Good first issues"

### Website (pdoom1-website repo)
- [ ] Donor landing page: "Why fund p(Doom)1?"
- [ ] Press kit page + downloadable assets
- [ ] Publish 90-second gameplay clip + 8 curated screenshots
- [ ] Public roadmap with 1/3/12 month tiers
- [ ] Safety & responsibility statement page
- [ ] Team + hiring plan page
- [ ] Budget page with low/medium/high outcomes
- [ ] Metrics page (honest early telemetry)
- [ ] Testimonials / reviewer blurbs section
- [ ] Public update cadence plan

### Data (pdoom-data repo)
- [ ] pdoom-data README overhaul: schema, provenance, contribution rules
- [ ] "Content pipeline win" demo: data-only update appears on site/game

## Definition of Done
- [ ] A tagged release is published
- [ ] pdoom1.com, repo README, and Releases all show the same current version and link to the same changelog
- [ ] At least one visible "content shipped via data pipeline" demo exists (gif/video + note)

issues.title: Multi-Turn Action Delegation System
issues.body:
# Multi-Turn Action Delegation System

## Summary
**PRIORITY: MEDIUM** - Implement multi-turn action sequences that allow delegation of decision-making to staff/managers, creating more strategic AP management.

## Strategic Context
- **Goal**: Enable complex actions like 'advertise -> receive applicants -> interview -> hire'
- **Benefit**: Reduces micro-management while adding strategic depth
- **Timeline**: Beta phase enhancement (post-alpha)

## Vision
Players can initiate longer-term actions that unfold over multiple turns:
1. **Recruitment Process**: Advertise (1 AP) -> Get applicants (2 turns) -> Interview (1 AP) -> Decision
2. **Research Projects**: Start research (2 AP) -> Progress updates (3 turns) -> Results  
3. **Marketing Campaigns**: Launch campaign (1 AP) -> Market response (4 turns) -> Reputation effects

## Current State Analysis
- **Action system**: Single-turn immediate effects (`actions.py`)
- **Staff system**: Static productivity bonuses (`game_state.py`)  
- **Manager system**: Basic unproductivity prevention
- **AP system**: Turn-based allocation with staff bonuses

## Proposed Architecture

### Core Components
1. **ActionQueue System**: Track multi-turn action progression
2. **DelegationManager**: Handle staff-managed action decisions  
3. **ActionTemplate System**: Define multi-stage action patterns
4. **ProgressTracker**: Show player status of ongoing actions

### Implementation Plan

#### Phase 1: Action Queue Foundation
```python
class MultiTurnAction:
    def __init__(self, action_type, stages, delegated_to=None):
        self.stages = stages  # List of action stages
        self.current_stage = 0
        self.delegated_to = delegated_to  # Staff member handling
        
class ActionQueue:
    def __init__(self):
        self.active_actions = []
    
    def process_turn(self, game_state):
        # Advance all active multi-turn actions
        for action in self.active_actions:
            action.advance_stage(game_state)
```

#### Phase 2: Delegation System
```python
class DelegationManager:
    def can_delegate(self, action_type, staff_member):
        # Check if staff has skills for action
        
    def delegate_decision(self, action, options, staff_member):
        # Staff makes decision based on AI/rules
```

#### Phase 3: UI Integration
- **Action Queue Display**: Show progress of ongoing actions
- **Delegation Interface**: Assign actions to specific staff
- **Progress Notifications**: Turn-by-turn updates on action status

## Example Action Flows

### Recruitment (3-4 turns)
1. **T1**: Player spends 1 AP to 'Post Job Advertisement'
2. **T2-T3**: Applications arrive (automatic)  
3. **T4**: Manager reviews applications (if delegated) OR player chooses (1 AP)
4. **T5**: Hiring decision executed

### Research Project (5-7 turns)
1. **T1**: Player spends 2 AP to 'Start Research Project'
2. **T2-T5**: Research progresses (automatic updates)
3. **T6**: Results available, player decides on publication/secrecy (1 AP)
4. **T7**: Effects applied to game state

## Integration Points
- **File**: `src/core/game_state.py` - Add ActionQueue to GameState
- **File**: `actions.py` - Define multi-turn action templates  
- **File**: `ui.py` - Add action queue display components
- **File**: `src/systems/delegation.py` - New delegation management system

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Players can initiate multi-turn actions
- [ ] Actions progress automatically each turn  
- [ ] Staff can be assigned to handle action decisions
- [ ] UI clearly shows action queue status
- [ ] Delegated actions reduce player micro-management
- [ ] AP costs are front-loaded appropriately

## Technical Challenges
1. **Save/Load**: Persist action queue state
2. **Balance**: Ensure delegated actions aren't overpowered
3. **UI Space**: Display action progress without clutter
4. **AI Logic**: Smart delegation decisions by AI staff

## Dependencies
- **Staff Management System**: Requires improved staff skill system
- **Action Framework**: May need action system refactor
- **Manager System**: Enhanced manager capabilities

## Priority: MEDIUM
**Effort**: 1-2 weeks (significant system addition)
**Impact**: Major gameplay depth enhancement  
**Risk**: Medium (complex system with many interactions)
**Timeline**: Beta phase (after alpha stability)

issues.title: Progressive finance and software management system
issues.body:
## Summary
Comprehensive finance management system where players upgrade from pen-and-paper to sophisticated software, with increasing complexity and automation options.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27 - extensive notes on finance system design.

## Core Concept
Players must manage increasing transaction volume and complexity. Better systems cost money but save time (AP). Creates interesting trade-off between efficiency and cost.

## Progression Tiers
### Tier 1: Manual (Free, High AP Cost)
- Pen and paper ledger
- Manual receipt tracking
- Scientists often forget receipts
- Manual payroll calculation
- High AP cost for basic accounting

### Tier 2: Spreadsheet ($100/year, Medium AP Cost)
- Excel/Sheets
- Formulas reduce errors
- Still manual data entry
- Better visibility
- Medium AP cost

### Tier 3: Basic Accounting ($1000/year, Low AP Cost)
- QuickBooks equivalent
- Automated categorization
- Invoice generation
- Still requires manual review
- Low AP cost

### Tier 4: Automated Payroll ($5000/year + per employee)
- Automatic payroll processing
- Tax calculations
- Direct deposit
- Minimal AP cost

### Tier 5: International Payroll ($15000/year + per employee)
- Multi-currency support
- International tax compliance
- Exchange rate handling
- Very low AP cost

### Tier 6: Enterprise ERP ($50000/year)
- Full automation
- Predictive budgeting
- Fraud detection
- Minimal AP cost, maximum functionality

## Required Initial Setup
Players must establish (or have in starting config):
- **Bank account** - where money lives
- **Email** - for communications
- **Tracking system** - how they know their balance (even if just mental math)

## Finance Actions & AP Costs
### Review Transactions (AP varies by system)
- Tier 1: 2 AP per 10 transactions
- Tier 6: 0 AP, auto-approved unless flagged

### Chase Missing Receipts (AP varies by culture)
- Some researchers forget receipts
- Requires follow-up
- Better culture = fewer missing receipts

### Approve Expenses (AP varies by system)
- Tier 1: Manual calculation and approval (high AP)
- Tier 6: Auto-approval with smart rules (0 AP)

### Payroll Processing (AP varies by system)
- Tier 1: Calculate hours, taxes, write checks (5 AP)
- Tier 4+: Automated (0 AP)

## Budget Management Features
### Project Budgets
- Researchers propose projects with budgets
  - Compute hours needed
  - Time estimate
  - Effort required
  - Travel for conferences
- Player approves/modifies budget
- Track spending vs budget
- Overspending warnings

### Recurring Expenses
- Rent, utilities, subscriptions
- Players must anticipate and plan
- Can doom yourself with commitments
- Example: Employee severance, lease agreements

### Commitments & Consequences
- Firing employees requires severance pay
- Breaking lease = penalty
- Subscription contracts
- Loan repayment schedules

## UI Enhancement Tie-In
Each software upgrade also enhances the game's UI:
- Tier 1: Basic text display
- Tier 3: Charts and graphs
- Tier 6: Beautiful dashboards, predictive analytics

## Complexity Scaling
As lab grows, transaction volume increases:
- 1-5 employees: ~50 transactions/month
- 5-20 employees: ~200 transactions/month  
- 20+ employees: ~500+ transactions/month

Without upgrades, this becomes unmanageable.

## Strategic Depth
### Trade-offs
- Hire admin staff OR buy better software?
- Cheap manual processes OR expensive automation?
- Focus budget on research OR infrastructure?

### Failure States
- Overdraft from missed payments
- Tax penalties from errors
- Researcher frustration from slow reimbursement
- Audit problems from poor records

## Implementation Phases
1. **Phase 1**: Basic transaction tracking and manual system
2. **Phase 2**: Software upgrade tiers 2-4
3. **Phase 3**: Project budgeting system
4. **Phase 4**: Advanced automation and ERP
5. **Phase 5**: UI enhancement tie-ins

## Related Systems
- Upgrades overhaul (#475)
- Project/research system (needs creation)
- Employee management
- Budget planning

## Design Principles
- Don't simulate actual accounting (boring)
- Represent complexity abstractly (transactions/month, AP cost)
- Make upgrades feel worth it
- Create genuine strategic choices
- Reward planning and investment in infrastructure

## Priority
High - core economic gameplay loop

## Notes
This is a major system that touches many parts of the game. Should be designed carefully and implemented incrementally.

issues.title: Comprehensive upgrades system overhaul
issues.body:
## Summary
The 'upgrades' section needs a comprehensive overhaul tied into useful office and operational expenses.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. Current upgrades feel disconnected from actual gameplay needs.

## Proposed Categories
### Office & Facilities
- Workspace quality (desks, chairs, lighting)
- Kitchen and amenities
- Meeting rooms
- Security systems
- Location upgrade (move to better office)

### Equipment & Infrastructure
- Compute clusters
- Development tools
- Network infrastructure
- Backup systems

### Software & Systems
- Accounting software (see #475)
- Project management tools
- Communication platforms
- HR systems

### Research Tools
- Datasets
- Specialized hardware
- Cloud credits
- Academic subscriptions

## Mechanics
- Each upgrade has:
  - Upfront cost
  - Ongoing maintenance
  - Tangible gameplay benefit
  - Clear prerequisite chain

## Integration
- Tied to budget management
- Visible in office representation
- Affects researcher productivity/morale
- Strategic choices: what to prioritize?

## Related Systems
- Office outfitting (#467)
- Finance management (#475)
- Personnel system

## Priority
High - core gameplay loop improvement

issues.title: Discoverable frontier labs and organization emergence system
issues.body:
## Summary
Re-add the ability to discover frontier labs and other organizations. Organizations instantiate invisibly and start contributing to game effects, becoming discoverable as player gains fame/reputation.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. The AI safety field shouldn't be just the player - there should be a dynamic ecosystem.

## Mechanics
### Silent Instantiation
- Organizations spawn at game start or during play
- They have their own budgets, researchers, projects
- They affect global variables (P(doom), capabilities progress, etc.)
- Initially invisible to player

### Discovery Threshold
- Player discovers orgs through:
  - Reputation milestones
  - Publishing in same areas
  - Conference attendance
  - Media coverage
  - Direct investigation actions

### Early Discovery Rewards
- "You discovered DeepMind before they became famous!"
- Early collaboration opportunities
- Recruitment from their staff
- Track their progress

### Observable Threshold
- Low observability: only know big labs (OpenAI, DeepMind)
- High observability: discover small research groups, startups
- Reward: information is valuable for planning

## Benefits
- Dynamic, living world
- Reconnaissance has value
- Surprise and discovery
- Realistic ecosystem

## Related Systems
- Reputation system
- Organization tracking (needs refactor)
- Event system

## Priority
Enhancement - adds strategic depth and world-building

issues.title: Character creation and lab setup point allocation system
issues.body:
## Summary
Add optional character creation where players spend points allocating advantages for lab setup (location, starting funds, reputation, connections, etc.).

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. Give players agency over their starting conditions while keeping a default for those who want to jump in.

## Features
### Point Buy System
Players get X points to spend on:
- **Location**: Bay Area (expensive, talent pool) vs smaller cities (cheap, less talent)
- **Starting Capital**: More money = less points elsewhere
- **Reputation**: Start with academic credentials vs unknown
- **Network**: Have researcher friends to hire easily
- **Equipment**: Start with compute vs basic laptops
- **Institutional Support**: University affiliation, grants, etc.

### Default Option
- "Start Standard Game" button for players who don't want to optimize
- Balanced default setup

### Presets
- "Academic Spinoff" - university connections, low funds
- "Well-Funded Startup" - VC money, no reputation
- "Solo Researcher" - minimal everything, high autonomy

## Design Considerations
- Keep it simple (5-10 choices max)
- Make trade-offs meaningful
- Replayability: different builds = different experiences
- Balance: no "obviously best" choice

## Priority
Enhancement - adds replayability and player agency

issues.title: Office cosmetic shopping system
issues.body:
## Summary
Allow players to purchase small cosmetic items for their office by going shopping (plants, art, decorations, etc.).

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. Add personality and attachment to the office space.

## Features
- Shopping action (takes time/AP)
- Categories: plants, art, office toys, coffee machines, etc.
- Small costs but morale/culture benefits
- Visual representation in office view
- Optional: staff preferences (some love plants, others don't care)

## Examples
- Potted plants (+morale, need maintenance)
- Coffee machine (productivity boost, ongoing cost)
- Foosball table (team building)
- Whiteboard walls (collaboration bonus)
- Art (culture/prestige)

## Game Impact
- Small AP/budget sink
- Morale and culture building
- Personalization and attachment
- "Treat yo self" moments

## Related Systems
- Office visual representation (#470)
- Office outfitting (#467)
- Budget management

## Priority
Enhancement - nice-to-have feature, low priority

issues.title: Visual office representation on screen
issues.body:
## Summary
Display the office environment visually on screen, showing layout, furniture, equipment, and staff presence.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. Make the lab feel more tangible and alive.

## Features
- Top-down or isometric office view
- Show desks, equipment, common areas
- Staff presence indicators (who's in, who's traveling)
- Visual representation of upgrades (new equipment, better furniture)
- Could show activity: researchers collaborating, meetings, etc.

## Design Options
1. Static background with overlays
2. Simple 2D floor plan
3. Isometric view (StarCraft style)
4. Side-scrolling office (Game Dev Story style)

## Benefits
- Makes the lab feel real
- Visual feedback for upgrades
- Sense of growth and progress
- Attachment to the space and team

## Technical Considerations
- Asset requirements
- UI space allocation
- Performance impact

## Priority
Enhancement - significant UX improvement, requires art assets

issues.title: Employee travel fatigue and jet lag mechanics
issues.body:
## Summary
Employees are less effective around travel periods, with jet lag affected by travel class, sleep quality, and recovery time.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. Travel has real productivity costs.

## Mechanics
### Jet Lag Effects
- Reduced productivity for X turns after long-distance travel
- Severity based on time zone changes
- Recovery influenced by:
  - Travel class (business vs economy)
  - Pre/post-travel rest
  - Sleep quality
  - Individual constitution

### Budget Trade-offs
- Economy: cheap but longer recovery
- Business: expensive but minimal impact
- First class: very expensive, no productivity loss

### Game Balance
- Make travel meaningful: not just "send everyone everywhere"
- Budget pressure: save money or preserve productivity?
- Strategic timing: don't send researchers before critical deadlines

## Related Systems
- Travel system (#TBD)
- Personnel productivity
- Budget management

## Priority
Enhancement - adds strategic depth to travel decisions

issues.title: Travel and paper publication system
issues.body:
## Summary
Add travel mechanics for conferences and paper publication processes to the game.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. Research isn't just local work - it involves travel, conferences, and publication cycles.

## Features
### Travel
- Conference attendance (networking, reputation, recruitment)
- Visiting other labs (collaboration opportunities)
- Cost: flights, accommodation, per diem
- Time away from research

### Paper Publication
- Submission process with timelines
- Peer review cycles (can be rejected)
- Publication prestige (Nature vs arxiv)
- Citation tracking and reputation impact
- Costs: publication fees, travel to present

## Game Impact
- Papers increase reputation
- Conferences enable networking and hiring
- Budget management: travel vs research spending
- Time management: researchers away from work

## Priority
Enhancement - adds realism to research career progression
